segment.source: This article describes best practices for creating and displaying app settings.
segment.target: This article describes best practices for creating and displaying app settings.

segment.source: Guidelines for app settings
segment.target: Guidelines for app settings

segment.source: Guidelines for app settings
segment.target: Guidelines for app settings

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: App settings are the user-customizable portions of your app and live within an app settings page.
segment.target: App settings are the user-customizable portions of your app and live within an app settings page.

segment.source: For example, app settings in a news reader app might let the user specify which news sources to display or how many columns to display on the screen, while a weather app's settings could let the user choose between Celsius and Fahrenheit as the default unit of measurement.
segment.target: For example, app settings in a news reader app might let the user specify which news sources to display or how many columns to display on the screen, while a weather app's settings could let the user choose between Celsius and Fahrenheit as the default unit of measurement.

segment.source: This article describes best practices for creating and displaying app settings.
segment.target: This article describes best practices for creating and displaying app settings.

segment.source: example of a settings pane
segment.target: example of a settings pane

segment.source: Should I include a settings page in my app?
segment.target: Should I include a settings page in my app?

segment.source: Here are examples of app options that belong in an app settings page:
segment.target: Here are examples of app options that belong in an app settings page:

segment.source: Configuration options that affect the behavior of the app and don't require frequent readjustment, like choosing between Celsius or Fahrenheit as default units for temperature in a weather app, changing account settings for a mail app, settings for notifications, or accessibility options.
segment.target: Configuration options that affect the behavior of the app and don't require frequent readjustment, like choosing between Celsius or Fahrenheit as default units for temperature in a weather app, changing account settings for a mail app, settings for notifications, or accessibility options.

segment.source: Options that depend on the user's preferences, like music, sound effects, or color themes.
segment.target: Options that depend on the user's preferences, like music, sound effects, or color themes.

segment.source: App information that isn't accessed very often, such as privacy policy, help, app version, or copyright info.
segment.target: App information that isn't accessed very often, such as privacy policy, help, app version, or copyright info.

segment.source: Commands that are part of the typical app workflow (for example, changing the brush size in an art app) shouldn't be in a settings page.
segment.target: Commands that are part of the typical app workflow (for example, changing the brush size in an art app) shouldn't be in a settings page.

segment.source: To learn more about command placement, see Command design basics.
segment.target: To learn more about command placement, see Command design basics.

segment.source: General recommendations
segment.target: General recommendations

segment.source: Keep settings pages simple and make use of binary (on/off) controls.
segment.target: Keep settings pages simple and make use of binary (on/off) controls.

segment.source: A toggle switch is usually the best control for a binary setting.
segment.target: A toggle switch is usually the best control for a binary setting.

segment.source: For settings that let users choose one item from a set of up to 5 mutually exclusive, related options, use radio buttons.
segment.target: For settings that let users choose one item from a set of up to 5 mutually exclusive, related options, use radio buttons.

segment.source: Create an entry point for all app settings in your app setting's page.
segment.target: Create an entry point for all app settings in your app setting's page.

segment.source: Keep your settings simple.
segment.target: Keep your settings simple.

segment.source: Define smart defaults and keep the number of settings to a minimum.
segment.target: Define smart defaults and keep the number of settings to a minimum.

segment.source: When a user changes a setting, the app should immediately reflect the change.
segment.target: When a user changes a setting, the app should immediately reflect the change.

segment.source: Don't include commands that are part of the common app workflow.
segment.target: Don't include commands that are part of the common app workflow.

segment.source: Entry point
segment.target: Entry point

segment.source: The way that users get to your app settings page should be based on your app's layout.
segment.target: The way that users get to your app settings page should be based on your app's layout.

segment.source: Navigation pane
segment.target: Navigation pane

segment.source: For a nav pane layout, app settings should be the last item in the list of navigational choices and be pinned to the bottom:
segment.target: For a nav pane layout, app settings should be the last item in the list of navigational choices and be pinned to the bottom:

segment.source: app settings entry point for nav pane
segment.target: app settings entry point for nav pane

segment.source: App bar
segment.target: App bar

segment.source: If you're using an app bar or tool bar, which is usually part of a hub or tabs/pivots navigational layout, place the entry point last item in the "More" flyout menu.
segment.target: If you're using an app bar or tool bar, which is usually part of a hub or tabs/pivots navigational layout, place the entry point last item in the "More" flyout menu.

segment.source: If greater discoverability for the settings entry point is important for your app, place the entry point directly on the app bar and not within the "More" flyout menu.
segment.target: If greater discoverability for the settings entry point is important for your app, place the entry point directly on the app bar and not within the "More" flyout menu.

segment.source: app settings entry point for app bar
segment.target: app settings entry point for app bar

segment.source: Hub
segment.target: Hub

segment.source: If you're using a hub layout, the entry point for app settings should be placed inside the "More" flyout menu of an app bar.
segment.target: If you're using a hub layout, the entry point for app settings should be placed inside the "More" flyout menu of an app bar.

segment.source: Tabs/pivots
segment.target: Tabs/pivots

segment.source: For a tabs or pivots layout, we don't recommended placing the app settings entry point as one of the top items within the navigation.
segment.target: For a tabs or pivots layout, we don't recommended placing the app settings entry point as one of the top items within the navigation.

segment.source: Instead, the entry point for app settings should be placed inside the "More" flyout menu of an app bar.
segment.target: Instead, the entry point for app settings should be placed inside the "More" flyout menu of an app bar.

segment.source: Master-details
segment.target: Master-details

segment.source: Instead of burying the app settings entry point deeply within a master-details pane, make it the last pinned item on the top level of the master pane.
segment.target: Instead of burying the app settings entry point deeply within a master-details pane, make it the last pinned item on the top level of the master pane.

segment.source: Layout
segment.target: Layout

segment.source: On both desktop and mobile, the app settings window should open full-screen and fill the whole window.
segment.target: On both desktop and mobile, the app settings window should open full-screen and fill the whole window.

segment.source: If your app settings menu has between up to four top-level groups, those groups should cascade down one column.
segment.target: If your app settings menu has between up to four top-level groups, those groups should cascade down one column.

segment.source: Desktop:
segment.target: Desktop:

segment.source: layout for app settings page on desktop
segment.target: layout for app settings page on desktop

segment.source: Mobile:
segment.target: Mobile:

segment.source: layout for app settings page on phone
segment.target: layout for app settings page on phone

segment.source: "About" section and "Give feedback" button
segment.target: "About" section and "Give feedback" button

segment.source: If you need an "About this app" section in your app, create a dedicated app settings page for that.
segment.target: If you need an "About this app" section in your app, create a dedicated app settings page for that.

segment.source: If you want a "Give Feedback" button, place that toward the bottom of the "About this app" page.
segment.target: If you want a "Give Feedback" button, place that toward the bottom of the "About this app" page.

segment.source: "Terms of Use" and "Privacy Statement" should be hyperlink buttons with wrapping text.
segment.target: "Terms of Use" and "Privacy Statement" should be hyperlink buttons with wrapping text.

segment.source: "about this app" section with "give feedback" button
segment.target: "about this app" section with "give feedback" button

segment.source: Recommendations
segment.target: Recommendations

segment.source: App settings page content
segment.target: App settings page content

segment.source: Once you have a list of items that you want to include in your app settings page, consider these guidelines:
segment.target: Once you have a list of items that you want to include in your app settings page, consider these guidelines:

segment.source: Group similar or related settings under one settings label.
segment.target: Group similar or related settings under one settings label.

segment.source: Try to keep the total number of settings to a maximum of four or five.
segment.target: Try to keep the total number of settings to a maximum of four or five.

segment.source: Display the same settings regardless of the app context.
segment.target: Display the same settings regardless of the app context.

segment.source: If some settings aren't relevant in a certain context, disable those in the app settings flyout.
segment.target: If some settings aren't relevant in a certain context, disable those in the app settings flyout.

segment.source: Use descriptive, one-word labels for settings.
segment.target: Use descriptive, one-word labels for settings.

segment.source: For example, name the setting "Accounts" instead of "Account settings" for account-related settings.
segment.target: For example, name the setting "Accounts" instead of "Account settings" for account-related settings.

segment.source: If you only want one option for your settings and the settings don't lend themselves to a descriptive label, use "Options" or "Defaults."
segment.target: If you only want one option for your settings and the settings don't lend themselves to a descriptive label, use "Options" or "Defaults."

segment.source: If a setting directly links to the web instead of to a flyout, let the user know this with a visual clue, such as "Help (online)" or "Web forums" styled as a hyperlink.
segment.target: If a setting directly links to the web instead of to a flyout, let the user know this with a visual clue, such as "Help (online)" or "Web forums" styled as a hyperlink.

segment.source: Consider grouping multiple links to the web into a flyout with a single setting.
segment.target: Consider grouping multiple links to the web into a flyout with a single setting.

segment.source: For example, an "About" setting could open a flyout with links to your terms of use, privacy policy, and app support.
segment.target: For example, an "About" setting could open a flyout with links to your terms of use, privacy policy, and app support.

segment.source: Combine less-used settings into a single entry so that more common settings can each have their own entry.
segment.target: Combine less-used settings into a single entry so that more common settings can each have their own entry.

segment.source: Put content or links that only contain information in an "About" setting.
segment.target: Put content or links that only contain information in an "About" setting.

segment.source: Don't duplicate the functionality in the "Permissions" pane.
segment.target: Don't duplicate the functionality in the "Permissions" pane.

segment.source: Windows provides this pane by default and you can't modify it.
segment.target: Windows provides this pane by default and you can't modify it.

segment.source: Add settings content to Settings flyouts
segment.target: Add settings content to Settings flyouts

segment.source: Present content from top to bottom in a single column, scrollable if necessary.
segment.target: Present content from top to bottom in a single column, scrollable if necessary.

segment.source: Limit scrolling to a maximum of twice the screen height.
segment.target: Limit scrolling to a maximum of twice the screen height.

segment.source: Use the following controls for app settings:
segment.target: Use the following controls for app settings:

segment.source: Toggle switches: To let users set values on or off.
segment.target: Toggle switches: To let users set values on or off.

segment.source: Radio buttons: To let users choose one item from a set of up to 5 mutually exclusive, related options.
segment.target: Radio buttons: To let users choose one item from a set of up to 5 mutually exclusive, related options.

segment.source: Text input box: To let users enter text.
segment.target: Text input box: To let users enter text.

segment.source: Use the type of text input box that corresponds to the type of text you're getting from the user, such as an email or password.
segment.target: Use the type of text input box that corresponds to the type of text you're getting from the user, such as an email or password.

segment.source: Hyperlinks: To take the user to another page within the app or to an external website.
segment.target: Hyperlinks: To take the user to another page within the app or to an external website.

segment.source: When a user clicks a hyperlink, the Settings flyout will be dismissed.
segment.target: When a user clicks a hyperlink, the Settings flyout will be dismissed.

segment.source: Buttons: To let users initiate an immediate action without dismissing the current Settings flyout.
segment.target: Buttons: To let users initiate an immediate action without dismissing the current Settings flyout.

segment.source: Add a descriptive message if one of the controls is disabled.
segment.target: Add a descriptive message if one of the controls is disabled.

segment.source: Place this message above the disabled control.
segment.target: Place this message above the disabled control.

segment.source: Animate content and controls as a single block after the Settings flyout and header have animated.
segment.target: Animate content and controls as a single block after the Settings flyout and header have animated.

segment.source: Animate content using the enterPage or EntranceThemeTransition animations with a 100px left offset.
segment.target: Animate content using the enterPage or EntranceThemeTransition animations with a 100px left offset.

segment.source: Use section headers, paragraphs, and labels to aid organize and clarify content, if necessary.
segment.target: Use section headers, paragraphs, and labels to aid organize and clarify content, if necessary.

segment.source: If you need to repeat settings, use an additional level of UI or an expand/collapse model, but avoid hierarchies deeper than two levels.
segment.target: If you need to repeat settings, use an additional level of UI or an expand/collapse model, but avoid hierarchies deeper than two levels.

segment.source: For example, a weather app that provides per-city settings could list the cities and let the user tap on the city to either open a new flyout or expand to show the settings options.
segment.target: For example, a weather app that provides per-city settings could list the cities and let the user tap on the city to either open a new flyout or expand to show the settings options.

segment.source: If loading controls or web content takes time, use an indeterminate progress control to indicate to users that info is loading.
segment.target: If loading controls or web content takes time, use an indeterminate progress control to indicate to users that info is loading.

segment.source: For more info, see Guidelines for progress controls.
segment.target: For more info, see Guidelines for progress controls.

segment.source: Don't use buttons for navigation or to commit changes.
segment.target: Don't use buttons for navigation or to commit changes.

segment.source: Use hyperlinks to navigate to other pages, and instead of using a button to commit changes, automatically save changes to app settings when a user dismisses the Settings flyout.
segment.target: Use hyperlinks to navigate to other pages, and instead of using a button to commit changes, automatically save changes to app settings when a user dismisses the Settings flyout.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows�10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows�10.
